I challenge anyone to come to St. Vincent and then tell me their economic plan is to cut their funds more to eliminate the estate tax.
Here's my question: why does government exist if not to take care of homeless kids?  What the hell are we doing if we can't do that right?
Back to the kids - they are stuck in the shelter for months bc there is nowhere else to go. One bookcase of books and one tiny bin of toys.
The staff are amazing - they try to perform miracles, but the shelter is overflowing and bleeding money.  Demand is up and finding is down.
The ceiling tiles are falling down. The staff make less than a living wage and are the edge of poverty themselves.
Their air conditioning broke and they have no money to fix it. It was over 100 degrees inside for a week. Again, there are often 25 kids.
St. Vincent is so crowded that the old metal frame beds basically touch each other w barely enough space to get into the top bunk.
St. Vincent is the biggest shelter in the state. 120 people on average, sometimes as many as 25 children.

And as recently as this spring, #SCOTUS upheld Connecticut's ban on sale of assault weapons.
(7) Scalia SPECIFICALLY notes the constitutionality of background checks, bans on certain weapons, other conditions on commercial sales.
(6) But Scalia is crystal clear in Heller: "Like most rights, the right secured by the Second Amendment is not unlimited."
(5) But 2008 changes two centuries of case law.  Heller v. DC, 217 later, reads into #2A an individual right to bear arms in 5-4 decision.
(4) For instance, in 1939 #SCOTUS holds #2A "does not curtail legislature’s power to regulate the nonmilitary use and ownership of weapons.”
(3) And for 217 years following ratification, #SCOTUS consistently held that #2A didn't include an individual right to bear arms.
(2) As Justice Stevens notes in Heller, it would have been easy for drafters to explicitly protect the individual right.  But they didn't.
(1) Madison intentionally qualified the right to bear arms as being part of the need for a well regulated militia.
